title: George Doucett
text:
George Henry Doucett (May 16, 1897 – May 1, 1974) was a <a href="Canadian">Canadian</a> politician. He was a <a href="Progressive%20Conservative%20Party%20of%20Ontario">Progressive Conservative</a> member of the <a href="Legislative%20Assembly%20of%20Ontario">Legislative Assembly of Ontario</a> from 1937 to 1957 and a member of the <a href="House%20of%20Commons%20of%20Canada">House of Commons of Canada</a> from 1957 to 1965. He represented the <a href="Lanark%20%28provincial%20electoral%20district%29">provincial</a> and <a href="Lanark%20%28electoral%20district%29">federal</a> ridings of Lanark in eastern Ontario. He was a member of cabinet in the provincial governments of <a href="George%20A.%20Drew">George Drew</a>, <a href="Thomas%20Laird%20Kennedy">Thomas Kennedy</a> and <a href="Leslie%20Frost">Leslie Frost</a>. He has the distinction of being the last Canadian federal <a href="Member%20of%20Parliament%20%28Canada%29">Member of Parliament</a> to be acclaimed into office.
Background.
Doucett was born in Ramsay Township located in <a href="Lanark%20County%2C%20Ontario">Lanark County, Ontario</a>, the son of Joseph Doucett and Martha Irwin, he was a farmer and insurance broker before entering politics. He was married to Mona Middleton in 1965 at the age of 68 while Mona was 60.
Politics.
At the age of 21 he was elected as a township councillor of the Ramsay Council. In 1928, he was elected <a href="Reeve%20%28Canada%29">reeve</a> and was elected Warden of Lanark County in 1935.
In <a href="1937%20Ontario%20general%20election">1937</a>, he was elected to the Ontario Legislature representing the riding of <a href="Lanark%20%28provincial%20electoral%20district%29">Lanark</a>. A member of the <a href="Progressive%20Conservative%20Party%20of%20Ontario">Progressive Conservative Party of Ontario</a>, he was re-elected in <a href="1943%20Ontario%20general%20election">1943</a>, <a href="1945%20Ontario%20general%20election">1945</a>, <a href="1948%20Ontario%20general%20election">1948</a>, <a href="1951%20Ontario%20general%20election">1951</a>, and <a href="1955%20Ontario%20general%20election">1955</a>. From 1943 to 1951, he was the Minister of Public Works and the Minister of Highways.
Upon the death of the federal Member of Parliament for Lanark, <a href="William%20Gourlay%20Blair">William Gourlay Blair</a>, in 1957, Doucett resigned from the Ontario Legislature and was acclaimed as a Member of Parliament in a 1957 by-election. He was re-elected in <a href="1958%20Canadian%20federal%20election">1958</a>, <a href="1962%20Canadian%20federal%20election">1962</a>, and <a href="1963%20Canadian%20federal%20election">1963</a>. He did not run in <a href="1965%20Canadian%20federal%20election">1965</a>.
